page.title: 16THE THREE PUBS
page.content: { THE THREE PUBS} The Three Tuns gets its name from 3 tonnes of wine which were taken from a French shipwreck by a 'wrecker'. It is situated in the square between the church and a shop. It was rebuilt in 1910 with local stone. The White Hart,which forms one side of the square, was converted from thatched cottages in 1700 and became a coaching inn that housed 2 horse buses. The famous tenor singer, Charles Ingledon, was born there in 1750. He sang before royalty all over the world. The pub has a collection of horse brasses and old photos of St. Keverne. The Five Pilchards, in Porthallow, has a remarkable collection of artefacts from shipwrecks and many photographs of this small fishing village taken at the turn of the century.
